no.nibio.vips.2_0.models.DELIARADIC.description;"THE PEST: Cabbage root fly larvae feed on the roots of brassicas
column2: with damage being dependant on the crop type
column3: growth stage and growing conditions. The cabbage root fly adults begin to lay eggs 5-7 days after emergence.  Newly transplanted or recently emerged crops are most at risk as the root systems are less developed.

column1: THE DECISION: Treatments may need to be applied soon after adults arrive in the crop
column2: before subsequent larvae tunnel into the crop roots.

column1: THE MODEL: The model determins the start of egg laying as 160 degree-days (day-degrees) based on soil temperature (10 cm)
column2: over a base of temperature of 4 °C)
column3: OR based on the standard air temperature (2 m above the soil surface) at the same locations
column4: egg laying starts at 210 degree days.

column1: THE PARAMETERS: The model uses Daily soil OR air temperature
SOURCE: NIBIO
column2: Norway.

column1: ASSUMPTIONS: Be aware that in areas with field covers (plastic
column2: single or double non-woven covers
column3: etc.) with early crops the preceding season (either on the current field or neighboring fields)
column4: the flight period can start earlier due to higher soil temperature under the covers. This model should be used in combination with direct observations of eggs in the field. This is due to large variability and to get an idea of the severity of attack. The model only applies for cabbage fly
column5: not turnip fly.

column4: da ihr Wurzelsystem noch nicht so weit entwickelt ist.

column2: bevor die Larven in die Wurzeln der Pflanze eindringen.

no.nibio.vips.2_0.models.NAERSTADMO.description;"The model is based on several years of experiments where trap plants have been placed next to a potato field infected with late blight. Infections on these plants have been correlated with weather conditions the day of exposure
column2: and this is the data the model is based on. The model predicts if there are favourable conditions for spore production and the following spread
column3: survival and infection of these spores. The model produces an infection risk
column4: and a value of 2.5 corresponds to one spot of late blight on each trap plant exposed. This value of 2.5 is the threshold where the model issues a warning.

column1: SOURCE:
ASSUMPTIONS:
REFERENCE: ";"Das Modell basiert auf mehrjährigen Versuchen
column2: bei denen Fangpflanzen neben einem mit Kraut- und Knollenfäule infizierten Kartoffelfeld aufgestellt wurden. Die Infektionen dieser Pflanzen wurden mit den Wetterbedingungen am Tag der Exposition korreliert
column3: und auf diese Daten stützt sich das Modell. Das Modell sagt voraus
column4: ob günstige Bedingungen für die Sporenproduktion und die anschließende Ausbreitung
column5: das Überleben und die Infektion dieser Sporen herrschen. Das Modell errechnet ein Infektionsrisiko
column6: und ein Wert von 2
column7: 5 entspricht einem Befall mit Kraut- und Knollenfäule auf jeder exponierten Fangpflanze. Der Wert von 2
column8: 5 ist die Schwelle
column9: ab der das Modell eine Warnung ausgibt.

column2: v katerih so bile privabilne rastline posajene poleg krompirjevega polja

column4: ali so ugodni pogoji za nastanek spor ter njihovo širjenje
column5: preživetje in okužbo. Model določa tveganje okužbe
column6: pri čemer vrednost 2
column7: 5 ustreza enemu žarišču krompirjeve plesni na vsaki izpostavljeni privabilni rastlini. Vrednost 2
column8: 5 je prag
column9: pri katerem model izda opozorilo.

no.nibio.vips.2_0.models.NEGPROGMOD.description;"THE PEST: Potato late blight
column2: caused by the fungus-like organism Phytophthora infestans causes severe damage to the foliage and can infect the tubers at harvest. THE DECISION: The model is designed to guide the timing of the first late blight fungicide application
column3: when used in combination with other agronomic risk factors.  THE MODEL: The model uses weather data to estimate the ‘epidemic free’ period (‘negative prognosis’) by calculating the accumulated blight risk from the date of crop emergence. The model guides the first spray timing at the end of the ‘epidemic free’ period.  THE PARAMETERS: From the date of crop emergence
column4: daily risk values are accumulated based on weather data (temperature
column5: relative humidity and precipitation). The risk is an accumulated value of how the weather affects late blight germination/infection
column6: sporulation and growth. All processes are corrected for inhibition due to drying. After the accumulated risk has reached certain thresholds
column7: there is likely to be moderate or high blight risk.  SOURCE: The model was first introduced by Schrodter and Ullrich in Germany in the 1970s and has been widely used in Europe since.   ASSUMPTIONS: The model is based on weather data.  Other agronomic factors
column8: such as time of row closure
column9: cultivar susceptibility
column10: the presence or absence of blight inoculum sources
column11: are not included in the risk estimate. It is not applicable to potatoes grown under protection.   REFERENCE: After the original paper by Ullrich
column12: J. & Schrödter
column14: the negative prognosis model was tested in other countries (e.g. by Taylor M. C. 2003 in the UK) and was commonly combined with other models to guide subsequent fungicide applications.  Combined models
column15: such as NegFry
column16: have been tested in many countries
column17: e.g. by Hansen J. G. et al.
column18: 1995 in Denmark; ";"SCHADERREGER: Die Kraut- und Knollenfäule der Kartoffel
column19: die durch den pilzähnlichen Organismus Phytophthora infestans ausgelöst wird
column20: verursacht schwere Schäden an den Blättern und kann die Knollen bei der Ernte infizieren.
